moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. Bg5 Ne4 3. Bf4 d5 4. e3 Bf5 5. f3 Nd6
comment:
A rare continuation, which was played in the 1986 Soviet Union Ch. between
Efimov - Kuzmin. White continued with 6.g4 Bg6 7.Nc3 e6 8.Qd2 h5 9.g5 Nd7 10.
0-0-0 and had the edge.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. Bg5 Ne4 3. Bf4 d5 4. e3 Bf5 5. f3 Nd6 6. Nc3 e6 7. Qe2 Be7 8. O-O-O Bg6
1. d4 Nf6 2. Bg5 Ne4 3. Bf4 d5 4. e3 Bf5 5. f3 Nd6 6. Nc3 e6 7. Qe2 Be7 8. O-O-O Bg6 9. e4 c6 10. h4 h5 11. Re1 Nc4 12. Qf2 Bb4 13. Bxc4 dxc4 14. Nge2 Nd7 15. Qg3 Nf6 16. Rd1 O-O
comment:
I had expected 16...Qd7 followed by
Queenside castling. With oposite side castling White will engage the Black h
pawn first.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. Bg5 Ne4 3. Bf4 d5 4. e3 Bf5 5. f3 Nd6 6. Nc3 e6 7. Qe2 Be7 8. O-O-O Bg6 9. e4 c6 10. h4 h5 11. Re1 Nc4 12. Qf2 Bb4 13. Bxc4 dxc4 14. Nge2 Nd7 15. Qg3 Nf6 16. Rd1 O-O 17. Bg5 Qb8 18. Qf2 Re8 19. Bxf6 gxf6 20. Qe3 f5 21. g4 hxg4 22. h5 Bh7 23. fxg4 fxe4 24. g5 Bf5 25. Nxe4 Bxe4
comment: So two Knights are better than two Bishops!
